Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Boaz Haberman is "Inverse problems for partial differential equations." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Chicago, and the sponsoring scientist is Carlos Kenig.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to study certain imaging problems. These problems relate to physical equations from quantum mechanics. The PI studied special solutions to the equations under various assumptions. The PI focused on the case where the coefficients of the equations are not smooth. In this case the existence of solutions is difficult to establish.

 

To produce these solutions, the PI developed a set of estimates and a framework for organizing these estimates. The organizing framework was a new category of function spaces based on algebraic ideas. The PI also developed a general procedure for producing these categories of function spaces. It extended earlier procedures by describing continuous collections of spaces in an algebraic way. 

 

The new framework for constructing function spaces could be useful for organizing multilinear estimates in harmonic analysis. In particular, it provides a systematic way to keep track of how estimates may depend on parameters. It could also be useful in other fields of mathematics, as it is rather general. It would be interesting to see whether there are other useful categories which may be constructed in this way. Finally, the construction relates to basic problems in category theory and could be of interest in category-theoretic logic.
